pages.raw_output: <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 79, 195, 149]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 92, 767, 108]]<|/det|> UNIVERSITY OF CAMBRIDGE INTERNATIONAL EXAMINATIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 108, 470, 123]]<|/det|> General Certificate of Education <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 122, 608, 138]]<|/det|> Advanced Subsidiary Level and Advanced Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 171, 195, 182]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 149, 199]]<|/det|> NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 233]]<|/det|> CENTRE <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 214, 425, 259]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 740, 92]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 94, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 798, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the resistivity of a metal in the form of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 134, 180, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 875, 168]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the diameter \(d\) of the short sample of wire that is attached to the card. You may remove the wire from the card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 241, 876, 260]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 181, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 791, 291]]<|/det|>
Calculate the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the wire, in \(\text{m}^2\), using the formula

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 303, 541, 331]]<|/det|>
\[A = \pi d^2 \div 4\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 473, 875, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>A = .................................................... $\text{m}^2$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 146, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 505, 180, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 875, 539]]<|/det|>
Use the wire attached to the metre rule, one of the voltmeters and one of the resistors to set up the partial circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 549, 744, 730]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 749, 532, 767]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 780, 764, 797]]<|/det|>
There are two crocodile clips, one labelled K and the other labelled L.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 794, 808, 812]]<|/det|>
Place K and L so that the distance \(l\) between them is approximately \(30 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 826, 181, 844]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 826, 628, 844]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the distance \(l\) between K and L.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 856, 875, 875]]<|/det|>
<form>l = .................................................... m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
Use the other resistor and the other voltmeter to complete the circuit shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 119, 744, 358]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 373, 534, 392]]<|/det|>
<mark>[i]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 405, 180, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 405, 591, 425]]<|/det|>
Place the crocodile clip M at a distance \(l\) from L.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 420, 581, 440]]<|/det|>
The value of \(l\) should be the same as in (b)(ii).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 452, 144, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 452, 180, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 452, 425, 470]]<|/det|>
Switch on the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 482, 181, 501]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 482, 707, 501]]<|/det|>
Record the voltmeter readings \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\) as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 526, 876, 547]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{1} = ....................................................V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 559, 876, 579]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{2} = ....................................................V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 575, 876, 593]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 606, 180, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 606, 425, 625]]<|/det|>
Switch off the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 109]]<|/det|>
Change \(l\) and repeat **(b)(ii)**, **(b)(iv)** and **(c)** until you have six sets of readings of \(l\), \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\). For each set of readings, distances KL and LM should **both** be \(l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 77, 945, 109]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 108, 435, 144]]<|/det|>
Include values of \(\frac{V_1}{V_2}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 490, 876, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 143, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 510, 178, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 508, 645, 549]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{V_1}{V_2}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(l\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 520, 875, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 567, 181, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 567, 457, 586]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 567, 875, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 597, 181, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 608, 616]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 797, 875, 817]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 831, 875, 850]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ....................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 846, 876, 865]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 92]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 875, 138]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the change in shape of a rubber band when masses are hung from it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 507, 168]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 180, 727, 472]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 491, 532, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 757, 542]]<|/det|>
The rods of the two clamps must be at the same height above the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 625, 572]]<|/det|>
Position the stands so that the rubber band has no slack.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 585, 146, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 585, 594, 604]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the mass \(m\) of the mass hanger.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 648, 876, 666]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... [1]
